annotator_prompt:
Your name is . Your traits: username: annotator, age: 0, sex: unknown, sexual_orientation: unknown, demographic_group: unknown, current_employment: unknown, education_level: unknown, special_instructions: , personality_characteristics: ['smart', 'competent', 'neutral', 'unbiased'] Your instructions: You, the annotator, will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. You, the annotator, are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.

The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

. Your output, as the annotator, is only of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do NOT write anything else but the number of your annotation. As the annotator, annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:
logs: How do you know he is not proud of his cakes? Artists do not take pride in their work? Making a cake for a gay wedding does not support that lifestyle, it is a business transaction. Period. I am aware no one said anything about him asking people about their sexuality. I am sorry that was hard for you to understand. Is he going to ask everyone that comes in if the cake is for a gay wedding? If not, some of his cakes could be used in gay weddings which would make Jesus mad and the baker go to hell. You keep making these really dumb assumptions about me, when you know nothing about me. I am not confused, you are rude. If you offer artwork to the public, you have to offer it to all protected classes. Why would black people be discriminated against? Precedent. Ridiculous? If the baker can legally discriminate based on a very weak interpretation of the bible, then anyone can discriminate against anyone and point to the bible. Satanists can discriminate against Christians...
Toxicity=4

@FirstUser, you're missing the point. The baker isn't refusing service because of the customers' sexuality, but because of the message the cake conveys. It's a subtle but important distinction. If a customer asked for a cake with a swastika, would you force the baker to make it? Freedom of speech and religion protect the baker's right to choose what messages he promotes. As for your slippery slope argument, that's a logical fallacy. Just because one group might misuse a law doesn't mean it's not valid. Let's not stoop to name-calling, it doesn't help the discussion. Let's try to understand each other's perspectives, shall we?
Toxicity=3

@FirstUser, you're really reaching with that slippery slope argument. Just because someone might misinterpret a law doesn't invalidate the original intent. And let's not forget, the baker in question didn't ask about the customers' sexuality, he refused to make a cake for a gay wedding. That's discrimination, plain and simple. As for your biblical interpretation, I'm pretty sure Jesus was all about love and acceptance, not turning people away. And @WiseOwl71, while I agree with your point about the message, the baker didn't refuse to write a specific message on the cake, he refused to make a cake for a gay wedding. That's a big difference. Let's not twist the facts to fit our narrative.
Toxicity=3
Toxicity=1

@TechGuru88, you're so quick to judge, aren't you? Maybe the baker just didn't want to make a cake for a couple he didn't know. Ever think of that? And @doing_my_best24, you're comparing apples to oranges. A baker refusing to make a cake for a black couple is completely different from refusing to make a cake for a gay wedding. And who says the baker was even thinking about the message on the cake? Maybe he just didn't want to be a part of something he didn't agree with. It's his business, his rules. And don't even get me started on the whole 'Jesus was all about love' nonsense. You're all so quick to throw that around, but I bet none of you have ever actually read the Bible. Hypocrites, the lot of you.
Toxicity=3

@doing_my_best24, you're absolutely right. This isn't about the message on the cake, it's about the baker refusing service to a couple because of their sexuality. It's no different than refusing service to a black couple, and that's just plain wrong. I've seen a lot in my years, and one thing I know for sure is that love is love, no matter who it's between. As for @QueenOfChaos, you're way off base. This isn't about the baker's personal beliefs, it's about him providing a service to the public. And don't you dare throw out the 'Jesus was all about love' line like it's some kind of gotcha. I've been going to church for decades, and I know that Jesus taught us to love and accept everyone, not turn them away because of who they love. Let's not twist the facts to fit some narrow-minded agenda.
Toxicity=2

You're probably one of those 'love the sinner, hate the sin' types, aren't you? Hypocrites, the lot of you. And @moderator, I'm not attacking anyone, I'm just calling it like it is. You're just trying to shut down the conversation because you can't handle the truth. Free speech, remember? Or is that just for the opinions you agree with?
Toxicity=3

@QueenOfChaos, you're missing the point entirely. This isn't about your personal beliefs or what you think Jesus would do. It's about a business providing a service to the public. If a baker refuses to make a cake for a gay couple, that's discrimination, plain and simple. And don't give me that 'free speech' nonsense. Free speech doesn't mean you can discriminate against people. If you don't want to bake a cake for a gay couple, don't open a bakery. It's that simple. And @GoldenYears66, you're spot on. Love is love, no matter who it's between. Let's not let narrow-minded people like @QueenOfChaos drag us back to the dark ages.

We're all here to learn and grow, not to hurl insults.
